answers.author: Michael Van Milligen
answers.text:
John,
The answer is yes, but you will still need to demonstrate that fact. Try to find an internship or part-time opportunity that you can accomplish while you continuing working. 
There are many examples of people who have made the transition from a department leader (not just Police) to the City Manager's Office. I can give you three Police examples in Iowa alone. Pella, Iowa, Bettendorf, Iowa (both former Police Chiefs) and Dubuque, Iowa (I am a former Police Officer).
I worked for 7 years as a Police Officer in Carbondale, Illinois (home of Southern Illinois University) working nights and getting my Master's Degree in Public Affairs during the day. The Jackson County Sheriff's Department needed some administrative help, especially writing a major traffic safety grant. I worked for them part-time as a civilian Administrative Assistant, while continuing at the Police Department. That helped to demonstrate my abilities. I then left the Police Department to take a job as civilian Administrative Assistant to the Chief of Police in Skokie, Illinois. After doing that job for two years I was promoted into the City Manager's Office. 
I have been the City Manager in Dubuque, Iowa for 20 years. Call me if you want to visit (563-589-4110).
Mike

answers.text:
Thanks for your question John!
I’ve found some resources that might be helpful to you and your inquiry.  
ICMA posted an article all about having a role in local government management
http://icma.org/en/Page/100092/Local_Government_Management_The_Hottest_Career_Youve_Probably_Never_Heard_Of.
On the Knowledge Network I’ve found a course syllabus for City or County Management Course.  
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/302887/City_and_County_Management_Course_Syllabus 
You also might be interested in the ICMA Career Network.
http://icma.org/en/icma/career_network/home
Before you make a final decision about choosing City Manager, maybe an externship or fellowship would allow you to see into the day to day of a local government manager.
http://icma.org/en/icma/career_network/job_seekers/interns
Another thing you might want to do is search our Who’s Who database through the Knowledge Network for those with backgrounds in law enforcement.  You could contact them and ask how they broke out into the local government management profession.  Later this year, the Knowledge Network will have a resource specifically for those changing careers.  
In addition to your MPA program, another professional development program like Leadership ICMA or the Emerging Leaders Development Program might lead you to great connections and mentors for the future. 
http://icma.org/en/icma/career_network/career_development/leadership_icma
http://icma.org/en/icma/career_network/career_development/eldp
Don’t forget to check back to the Professional and Personal Development topic page for further details. 
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/topics/kn/Topic/211/Professional_and_Personal_Development
Let us know if we can be of any help to you in the future! 
Hilary Badger
Knowledge Network Intern
ICMA

author: John Davis
text: I am a fifteen year veteran of LE and currently hold the rank of Major as the Commander of the Parol Division of a small department in Georgia (60 FT personnel).  I have supervisory control over all phases of patrol operation from hiring to fleet services and policy implementation.  I am also currently in a MPA program and will be graduating next summer.  I have been considering moving into city management but I am wondering if my skills and experience will translate into the CM world?
title: Transition from Law Enforcement to CM
